prompt.p: A 55-year-old man presents to his GP complaining of difficulty getting up his stairs and generalized weakness. He has gained weight and denies dyspnoea but has a reduced exercise tolerance. His past medical history includes asthma and his medication includes salbutamol and long-term oral prednisolone. On examination there is reduced muscle power and bulk. His face seems puffy.
What is the cause of his proximal myopathy?

modalFeedback.p: Option B (Cushing's syndrome) is Correct. Iatrogenic use of steroid on a long-term basis causes Cushing's syndrome. Catabolism effects of the steroid cause reduction in muscle bulk.
Option A (Alcoholic myopathy) is Incorrect. There are no features of this disease.
Option C (Diabetes mellitus) is Incorrect. There are no features of this disease.
Option D (Hyperthyrodism) is Incorrect. There are no features of this disease.
Option E (Motor neuron disease) is Incorrect. There are no features of this disease.
